text: The Cape teal (Anas capensis) is a 44–46 cm long dabbling duck of open wetlands in sub-Saharan Africa. ==Biology== thumb This species is essentially non-migratory, although it moves opportunistically with the rains. Like many southern ducks, the sexes are similar. It is very pale and mainly grey, with a browner back and pink on the bill (young birds lack the pink). The Cape teal cannot be confused with any other duck in its range. It is a thinly distributed but widespread duck, rarely seen in large groups except the moulting flocks, which may number up to 2000. This species feeds on aquatic plants and small creatures (invertebrates, crustaceans and amphibians)Hockey, P.A.R., Dean, W.R.J., Ryan, P.G. (Eds). 2005. Roberts – Birds of Southern Africa, VIIth ed. The trustees of the John Voelcker bird book fund, Cape Town. obtained by dabbling. The nest is on the ground under vegetation and near water. This is a generally quiet species, except during mating displays. The breeding male has a clear whistle, whereas the female has a feeble "quack". The Cape teal is one of the species to which the Agreement on the Conservation of African-Eurasian Migratory Waterbirds (AEWA) applies. ==Gallery== File:Anas capensis -Lake Nakuru, Kenya-8.jpg|Lake Nakuru, Kenya File:Cape Teal, Serengeti.jpg|Serengeti NP File:Anas capensis, Austin Roberts.jpg|Austin Roberts sanctuary, South Africa File:Teal Cape 2015 08 22 10 26 06 9524.jpg|Darville, Pietermaritzburg, South Africa File:Teal Cape 2015 08 22 12 09 41 0150.jpg|Darville, Pietermaritzburg, South Africa File:Teal Cape 2015 08 22 10 26 45 9538.jpg|Darville, Pietermaritzburg, South Africa File:Teal Cape 2015 08 22 10 31 19 9561.jpg|Darville, Pietermaritzburg, South Africa File:Teal Cape 2015 08 22 11 53 23 9980.jpg|Darville, Pietermaritzburg, South Africa File:Teal Cape 2015 08 22 11 56 54 0011.jpg|Darville, Pietermaritzburg, South Africa File:Teal Cape 2015 08 22 12 07 05 0091.jpg|Darville, Pietermaritzburg, South Africa ==References== ==External links== * Species text in The Atlas of Southern African Birds.
